with a picture like this

and the agent then uses your favorite

in a real world environment

domains where your environment is made

so let me motivate this with a very
simple
example of a market say you're in the

and this market is made up of
two other shops that also sell paper and
compete with you and three customers
alice bob and carl
each of the shops has to decide at what
price they want to sell paper and they
have to manage their inventory
and the customers have to each decide
whether they want to buy paper how much
paper to buy and from which shop
now
no real world market is quite so
homogeneous
for one different customers could have
different preferences on cost versus
delivery time so for instance alice
might be someone who
is optimizing for cost and is willing to
wait longer to receive her paper
whereas carl might be someone who wants
his paper tomorrow and is willing to pay

similarly shops could have different
storage costs and that would in turn
constrain the way they could price and
how much inventory they would carry
and as you can see in this graph here
the agents could have different levels
of connectivity to each other
and that influences how much information
an agent has access to
for instance alice here is connected to
all three shops so she receives prices
from all three shops for his call is
only connected to one shop
and much of the uh
dynamics of
complex real-world systems really arises
from this heterogeneity of agents and
how that interplays with the
interactions of these agents so this
heterogeneity is a very important thing
to capture when you're modeling real
world systems
now let's do a simple thought experiment
let's say you control sharp z
and you are interested in evaluating
what would happen if you changed your

now the answer to this question is it

it depends on how alice and bob the

change their buying behavior in response

and it also depends on what are the
other options what are the what are the

so the impact also depends on how your

so all in all this is to say that
answering this question
really requires simulating how other
agents in the system change their
behavior in response
so how do you simulate that
and that's primarily what i'm going to
talk about is uh the approach that we
have developed in my team to use rl to
build agent-based simulators
so there are primarily three questions
that you need to answer to build an
agent-based simulation the first is how
do agents differ from each other
that is how do you specify this
heterogeneity of agents and we use
reward functions and the connectivity
graph between agents to do that
the second question is how do agents
behave how do you specify behaviors and
how do these behaviors evolve
and rl here is a really natural tool to
automatically learn agent behaviors and
policies the third question then is how
do you even know what types of agents
are present in the system because
clearly the dynamics of the system
depends pretty heavily on this
and here i will talk about our work that
we published a couple of years back on
using rl to calibrate the agent
composition using real data and that
makes
this set of simulation techniques very
powerful for applications
so let me dive in
with
the first question of how do you specify

mentioned one way in which agents are
different from each other is they have
different levels of connectivity and you
can
specify this as we do in our framework
using a deterministic or stochastic
network between agents
the second aspect in which agents differ
is that they make different trade-offs
because of differences in preferences
and constraints
and this we encode into the reward
function for agents
to make this more concrete let's go back
to the shop
and customer example from before
so let's say in the printer paper market
every
shop cares about three things
maximizing sales revenue minimizing
storage cost
and minimizing the shortfall between
their inventory and demand
now while every shop might care about
these three terms
they might care about it to varying
degrees
and you could capture that variation by
assigning different weights to these
terms in the reward function
so every shop has the same form for the
reward function but different weights
and you can get different types of
shocks
by specifying
these weights and the combination of
these weights in the reward function and
the connectivity parameters
are together referred to as the type
parameters for the agent
and you could do a very similar thing
for the customer
now i'm going to take this simple
printer paper market and extend that
into a financial market in a single
asset so let's say it's ibm stock
this market is consists of uh two types
of players there are market makers and
investors similar to the shops and
customers in our previous example
market makers have to decide
at what prices they are willing to buy
and sell stock and they have to manage
their inventory
investors have to decide whether to buy
sell or do nothing
but there are two key differences
in this market
all agents can both buy and sell stock
so they can they can transact in both
directions
and
every agent has an inventory and that
inventory can also be negative it simply
means that they are short the stock
the second key difference is that the
value of the inventory can fluctuate
with time and that is because the value
depends on the reference price for the
asset at the exchange and this gives
this kind of fluctuation
gives rise to what we call inventory
profit and loss or inventory p l and of
course you hope it's more profits than
loss
and it also gives rise to risk
that comes from the uncertainty of the
value of the inventory
so so similar to what we did with
shops and customers
we can set up the reward functions for
market makers and investors
by specifying the terms of the reward
function and then letting each agent put
different weights on these terms
so what do market makers care about
market makers care about maximizing
their sales revenue
and maybe meeting some market share
target
crucially they care about minimizing
risk from inventory
and you could have market makers that
are more risk covers and place a high
weight on this risk term in the reward
function
and then there might be others who are
less risk of us
similarly you could have different types
of investors
so let's say alice is a day trader and
she cares about maximizing her inventory
p l and minimizing her execution cost
and she doesn't care much about risk and
uh meeting some quantity target
whereas carl
might be a long-term investor and he
cares primarily about
executing some target quantity he has
identified say 100 shares of ibm
and he's identified this target based on
his investment thesis and that's what he
primarily cares about he cares much less
about the shorter term
inventory p l and execution cost
so now that we have set up reward
functions for the agents in this market
and ways to specify different types of
agents with these weightings
we are really
all set to use rl to learn policies for
these agents
now one way we could do this is to learn
a separate policy for each agent
after all i have been telling you how
they are different from each other
and we could use this by using the
agents each agent's experience that is
the stream of uh states actions and
rewards or observations actions and
rewards it sees to update its policy
the issue with this is that it is hard
to scale as the number of agents
increases
it is also unstable in its learning
dynamics
and importantly it doesn't really
leverage any of the commonality across
agents
so just because one market maker places
a slightly higher weight on the risk
term in the reward function doesn't mean
that its policy is entirely different
from that of other market makers
in our work we leverage
this commonality to make the learning
more efficient using what we call a
shared policy learning approach
in this approach we learn a common
shared policy across say all the market
makers and this policy pi takes as input
not just the observations of the agent
but also the agent's type parameters
lambda
and as i mentioned previously lambda
could be the weights the agent places in
the reward function as well as its
connectivity parameters
the policy this shared policy is then
trained with the experiences of all the
agents
and you could do this using a policy
gradient method like ppo which is what
we use
and
the main difference here is that you
also plug in the type parameters of the
agents as you're doing the updates
the advantage of this approach is that
we are able to learn a shared policy
that generalizes across the different
types of agents
and it is more efficient because it
leverages parameter sharing and the
experiences of all the agents to do the
updates and learn faster and in a more
stable way
so let's take a look at what this
uh
means for the rl based investor
in this uh simple illustrative example
that we that i have here
we set a quantity target of 75 percent

so every investor
is
essentially making a trade-off between

l term in the reward function
and after training the shared policy
what we've done here is do rollouts with

values for this weight and this is
really to explore and understand what
the shared policy has learned for
different types of investors
the blue line that you see in this plot
is the reference price for the
asset
and you can see when the when we set a
weight of zero for p l the shared policy
is
largely trying to meet the quantity
targets so it ends up buying most of the

25 of the time but you can see it's not

strategic about how it times these
trades it
it

but as you increase the weight
it starts to
uh
time the trades in a more careful manner
it's still for a weight of 0.25 it is
still trying to meet the quantity

is high
and as the weight increases further it
completely ignores the quantity target
and you start to see opportunistic
buying and selling behavior to maximize
p l
so what's really cool about this is that
you can simulate and generate a whole
range of behaviors using a single policy

you can do that simply by wearing the
type parameters for the agents
we see a similar thing for the rl based
market maker the our base market maker

just that the market maker learns to

so
because this is the market maker is both

but what is really interesting is that
the shared policy
also learns to modulate this behavior

aversion and connectivity parameters
so the
shared policy learns to skew more

which makes sense because in both of

in every for every single setting of
this agent composition that you're going

in the inner loop the you have an rl

what we proposed instead

its actions are to pick the next agent

based on the calibration loss
but
the
really nice thing that we can do here is

the calibrator learns and picks agent

in the simulation are able to adapt
